The  Project  is  designed  to  improve  the  urban  environment  and 
living  conditions,  and  to  promote  reforms  for  sustainable  and 
responsive  urban  management  in  about  10  small  towns.  It  is 
formulated  as  a  sector  loan  project,  requiring  the  towns  to 
demonstrate their commitment to the Project and the associated 
reforms,  thus  encouraging  a  demand-led approach. The Project 
blends  environmental  and  livelihood  improvements  with  reforms 
for  establishing and developing decentralized urban governance 
in small towns. Physical investments that include improvements 
to roads, drainage, sanitation and solid waste management, and 
village  upgrading  are  combined  with  civic  awareness  programs 
and  inclusive  processes  to  obtain  maximum  and  sustainable 
benefits from investments and to ensure effective targeting of the 
poor.  

Over the last 6 years, the urban environment in the Lao PDR has 
improved significantly with investments in Vientiane and the four 
secondary towns. However, a focus on the largest urban centers 
constrained  the  ability  of  the  urban  sector  to  realize  its  full 
potential  to  support  equitable  and  broad-based  development. 
Small towns have not benefited from the investments. This fact 
has  not  only  impoverished  the  small  towns’  residents,  but  also 
undermined  the  developmental  roles  of  these  towns  as  (i) 
provincial  and  district  centers;  (ii)  centers  of  marketing  and 
agricultural processing in the rural hinterland and economic links 
between rural, national, and international markets; and (iii) places 
offering  nonfarm  employment  to  the  rural  poor  who  are  mostly 
engaged  in  livelihoods  that  depend  on  natural  resources, 
threatening the country’s ecological sustainability. At this stage of 
urban  development  in  the  Lao  PDR,  when  Vientiane  and  the 
secondary  towns  have  already  developed  as  national  and 
regional centers, the focus of development effort needs to shift to 
small  urban  centers  to  support  broad-based  development  and 
reduce poverty within both urban and rural communities. There is 
a  need  to  improve  basic  infrastructure  and  services  to  attain  a 
reasonable  quality  of  life  for  the  towns’  people.  Physical 
investments need to be combined with livelihood improvements. 
Improvements  should  follow  inclusive  processes  to  respond  to 
community  needs  and  catalyze  the  resources  of  the  poor.  All

2. 
The  Lao  PDR  is  essentially  a  rural  country  with  about  18%  of  the  total  population  (0.85 
million) living in urban areas. However, since the mid 1980s, as a result of economic liberalization 
and expanded commercial and industrial opportunities in urban areas, growing numbers of rural 
people have been drawn to the urban areas in search of better livelihoods. Although the economy 
is still largely rural, the role of the urban sector is growing. During 1997 to 2001, the industry and 
services sector components of the gross domestic product increased at average annual rates of 8 
and  6.2%,  compared  with  5.3%  for  agriculture,  implying  the  higher  productivity  and  greater 
opportunities  in  urban  areas.  Vientiane,  the  capital  city,  is  the  largest  urban  center  with  a 
population of about 200,000. The four largest provincial capitals are called secondary towns, with 
populations of 20,000 to 60,000. An emerging category of urban settlements is the small  towns2 
with  populations  ranging  from  5,000  to  20,000  and  annual  growth  rates  of  up  to  4.3%.  These 
towns  perform  critical  administrative  functions  as  provincial  and  district  capitals,  and  are  the 
economic links between the rural areas and the national and international markets. They are the 
centers  of  immediate  markets,  transport  depots,  and  agricultural  processing  in  the  rural 
hinterland.  Large  numbers3  of  rural  people  commute  daily  to  the  towns  to  exchange  their  rural 
produce with urban goods and services. The towns offer the rural poor labor markets during off-
farm seasons. The nonfarm employment in the towns presents a viable alternative for the country 
where ecological sustainability is threatened by livelihoods4 dependent on natural resources.  
 
3. 
Over the last 6 years, the urban environment in the Lao PDR has improved significantly 
with  investments  in  Vientiane  and  the  four  largest  secondary  towns.  However,  a  focus  on  the 
largest  urban  centers  compromised  the  ability  of  the  urban  sector  to  realize  its  full  potential  to 
support  equitable  and  broad-based  development.  The  quality  of  life  and  urban  productivity  in 
small  towns  and  the  potential  developmental  role  that  small  towns  can  play  in  their  rural 
hinterland  are  constrained  by  the  grossly  inadequate  urban  infrastructure  and  services  that  are 
the focus of this Project. The project framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
4. 
The  towns  vary  widely  in  the  quality  and  coverage  of  urban  infrastructure  and  services. 
None  has  a  central  or  partial  sewerage  system,  and  existing  on-site sanitation systems are in 
poor condition because there are no septic waste collection or treatment systems. The absence 
of interconnected drainage networks results in frequent flooding after rainstorms. The percentage 
of  lined  primary  and  secondary  drainage  networks  varies  from  0  to  40%.  Water  in  the  roadside 
drains  is  contaminated  with  fecal  matter  from  on-site  sanitation  systems.  Drainage,  where  it 
exists,  becomes  blocked  with  silt  washed  from  the  unpaved  roads  during  the  rainy  season. 
Generally,  only  the  main  roads  are  surfaced,  but  they  are  often  in  bad  condition.  Other  roads, 
generally  gravel  or  earth,  are  invariably  dusty  during  dry  season  and  muddy  in  rainy  periods.

Maintenance  for  urban  roads  and  drainage  is  irregular  and  lacks  necessary  funding  and  clear 
arrangements.  Solid  waste  management  services  are  inadequate  with  no  regular  collection. 
Except one town, Xam Neua, the coverage of solid waste collection is no more than 12%.  None 
of  the  towns  have  a  sanitary  or  controlled solid waste disposal site.  Town  markets,  where  the 
economic  activity  revolves  around  and  where  the  poor  can  sell  their  produce  and  offer  their 
services  as  porters  and  cleaners,  are  in  poor  hygienic  conditions,  lacking  ventilation,  lighting, 
surfacing,  sanitation,  and  parking  areas.  The  health  and  productivity  of  the  population  in  these 
small urban centers are constantly undermined by poor environmental conditions.   
 
  
Tertiary infrastructure at the urban village level is also inadequate with a directly adverse 
5. 
impact  on  the  quality  of  life  of  the  village  communities,  especially  the  poor.  Access  is  generally 
poor  characterized  by  earthen  and  undrained  pavements  that  become  quagmires  in  the  wet 
season. The conditions are worse in the poorer villages. While there are no large aggregate poor 
communities  in  these  towns,  poverty  is  dispersed  throughout  the  urban  villages,  with  some 
villages accommodating much larger populations of the poor than others. Frequently, a few poor 
families  huddle  behind  the  homes  of  wealthier  villagers.  The  poor  live  on  undeveloped  plots 
without street frontage or proper access roads. The plots are often poorly drained and prone to 
flooding. Conditions are unhygienic, water- and feces-borne diseases are prevalent, undermining 
the health and income-earning ability of the poor. The situation is aggravated by the fact that the 
communities  generally  are  not  aware  of  the  links  between  health  and  environmental  conditions. 
Lack  of  access  to  basic  infrastructure  and  services  in  small  towns  is  both  a  cause  and 
consequence  of  poverty.  The  level  of  urban  infrastructure  and  services  in  small  towns  and  the 
investment requirements are presented in Appendix 2. 
 
Poverty incidence5 in small towns varies from 18 to 43% in line with the regional variations 
6. 
in poverty incidence in the Lao PDR. The majority of the towns are in the Northern region where 
the poverty incidence is highest. As a result, poverty incidence in the project towns is estimated at 
30%.  A  poverty  assessment  conducted  as  part  of  the  feasibility  study  suggests  that  the most 
commonly  expressed  cause  of  poverty  is  lack  of  a  permanent  occupation,  and  consequently,  a 
low and irregular income. In most cases, physical and social exclusion act together, resulting in a 
perpetual  poverty  cycle  of  poor  access  to  basic  infrastructure  and  services,  poor  health,  low 
productivity, and low incomes of the poor. The poorest of the poor6 depend on markets as their 
main  source  of  income,  where  they  sell  vegetables  and  forest  products,  or  offer  their  labor  as 
porters  and  cleaners.  The  vast  majority  of  the  middle-  and  upper-poor  groups7  are  engaged  in 
market  vending,  home-based  micro-enterprise,  and  small  retail  activities.  Existing  and  potential 
microentrepreneurs, however, are constrained by lack of access to institutional microfinance and 
associated services. Small loans needed by these groups are not available through the existing 
banking  system.  Most  households  report  finance  as  a  major  start-up  problem  in  establishing  a 
livelihood.

8. 
The  inadequate  infrastructure  and  services  and  poor  environmental  conditions  in  small 
towns  stem  from  the  fact  that  until  recently,  small  towns  had  the  lowest  priority  in  the  country’s 
development agenda and have benefited least from public investments. The Government is now 
keen on equitable growth and is concerned with the complementary and supportive role of small 
towns  in  broad-based  local  development.  The  Fifth  Five-Year  Socioeconomic  Plan  (2001-2005) 
prioritizes  planning  and  developing  basic  infrastructure  and  services  in  urban  areas,  including 
small  towns.  The  poverty  reduction  partnership  agreement,  signed  in  September  2001  by  ADB 
and the Government, includes small towns development as one of the key operational priorities to 
enhance reciprocal linkages between urban and rural areas, more specifically, (i) integrating rural 
producers  with  urban  markets,  (ii)  enabling  urban  entrepreneurs  to  trade  with  rural  people,  and 
(iii) facilitating access of the rural and urban population to international markets. The Government 
recognizes  that  this  vision  requires  interventions  to  meet  basic  human  needs  and  stimulate  the 
economy  in  small  towns.  The  Government’s  urban  sector  investment  plan  indicates  that  about 
$97 million is required to meet the investment needs in the next 10 years in the urban areas. This 
figure includes about $44 million for the needs of all the small towns including further investment 
needs  of  the  project  towns.  The  capital  investment  program  is  ambitious  and  suggests  that the 
investment projects need to be prioritized for the optimum use of scarce available resources. The 
likely sources of financing for urban sector investment needs are given in Appendix 2.    
 
9. 
The incidence of poverty in small towns results from lack of programs that could address 
the  multidimensional  nature  of  poverty.  The  limited  funds  in  the  context  of  large-scale major 
infrastructure needs have, so far, not reached the village level where the impact of investments 
could directly be felt  by the communities. While the lack of funds is a constraint on improvement 
programs,  a  major  problem  is  lack  of  effective  strategies  that  could  spark  the  initiatives  of  the 
poor  and  mobilize  the  resources  of  village  communities  in  improving  their  environment.  The 
recent  Government  policy  to  assign  to  the  villages  a  greater  role  in  development  provides  an 
immense  opportunity  to  promote  new  approaches  whereby  village  communities  can  become 
active  partners  in  the  development  process  of  their  own  villages.  However,  improving  basic 
infrastructure and services alone will not suffice to make a sustainable impact on the lives of the 
poor.  The  poverty  assessment  report  clearly  highlights  the  linkage  between  poor  environmental 
conditions  and  low  incomes.  It  is  essential that environmental improvements in small towns be 
complemented  with  interventions  to  enhance  livelihoods  and  thus  sustain  the  improved  living 
conditions of the poor.  
 
10. 
The  poor  living  conditions,  inadequate  infrastructure  and  services,  and  insufficient 
operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  also  arise  from  the  current  forms  of  centralized  urban 
management  and  limited  institutional  capacities.  The  current  institutional  framework  is  not 
conducive  to  delivering  services  efficiently  and  mobilizing  local  revenues.  Recognizing  the 
limitations  of  centralized  urban  management  in  an  increasingly  urbanizing  society,  the 
Government  launched  a  program  of  decentralization  in  1995.  Since  then,  the  Government  has 

  4

created  urban  development  administration  authorities  (UDAAs)  in  Vientiane  and  the  four  major 
secondary towns and envisages eventually transforming these authorities into autonomous urban 
local governments. With a number of prime ministerial (PM) decrees, decisions, and instructions, 
these  authorities  were  recognized  as  legal  entities  with  exclusive  responsibility  for  planning, 
managing, and providing infrastructure and services in urban areas. More importantly, they were 
empowered  to  raise  local  revenues  from  a  range  of  sources  to  increasingly  meet  their 
expenditure  for  the  urban  functions.  In  its  Fifth  Five-Year  Plan,  the  Government  reconfirms  its 
commitment  to  the  gradual  development  of  municipal  administrations  in  urban  areas  and 
acknowledges the need to extend the decentralization reforms to the small towns.      
 
11. 
The  review  of  past  UDAA  reforms  suggests  the  need  for  further  concerted  efforts  to 
maintain  the  momentum  for  reforms.  The  comprehensive  nature  of  the  decentralization  reforms 
requires  technical,  financial,  and  legal  interventions  by  a  number  of  agencies  at  various  levels. 
Although  the  PM  decrees  provide,  in  the  interim,  the  required  legal  basis  for  UDAA  operations, 
the  issue  of  lack  of  an  encompassing  and  permanent  legal  framework  for  urban  local 
governments  needs  to  be  resolved  in  the  medium  term  by  enacting  the  local  administration  bill 
being discussed within the Government. A review of the decentralization process also shows that 
the  Government  commitments  made  through  a  number  of  PM  decrees  and  decisions  have  not 
always  been  simultaneously  supported  by  other  concerned  agencies.  While  the  financial  and 
technical  progress  of  the  Vientiane  UDAA  (VUDAA)  was  relatively  promising,  the  progress  of 
UDAAs in some secondary towns has been constrained, in some cases, by inadequate support 
from provincial governments or, in other cases, failure of the concerned line ministries to actually 
transfer the assets, staff, and revenue collection function to UDAAs.  The future urban policy and 
institutional reform agenda should take into account the past experience and build on the reforms 
evolving over the last 6 years in the Lao PDR. Further reforms, which have formed the content of 
the  policy  dialogue  pursued  during  preparation  of  the  Project,  include  (i)  issuing  PM  decrees  to 
establish, in small urban centers, UDAAs with mandate to plan and provide urban infrastructure 
and  services;  (ii)  empowering  UDAAs  to  have  their  own  budget  and  raise  local  revenues  by 
levying and collecting service charges and fees similar to those being implemented in Vientiane; 
and (iii) supporting capacity building for UDAAs to perform initially as project implementing units 
and to gradually become competent urban entities.

13. 
Experience  with  earlier  ADB  assistance  suggests  that  institutional  reforms  require  the 
concerted efforts of all involved parties, and takes a period of time longer than what is envisaged. 
Reforms need to be supported by extensive and long-term capacity building. The role of UDAAs 
has to be clearly understood by provincial and district authorities, which must be involved in the 
process. Delayed establishment of UDAAs and their inadequate involvement, from the outset in 
the secondary towns development project have meant that opportunity to transfer knowledge and 
skills  to  UDAAs  through  the  project  has  been  limited.  Project-specific  lessons  show  that 
centralized  project  implementation  has  limitations  in  providing  the  towns  with  a  sense  of 
ownership and ensuring sustainability of investments. The experience also reveals the need for a 
demand-responsive approach, requiring the towns’ commitment to the Project, and incorporating 
participatory processes to better target the needs of the poor, maximize sustained benefits from 
the  improvements,  and  solicit  community  support  for  the  project  and  UDAA  reforms.  Lessons 
learned from earlier ADB assistance are in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
14. 
At  this  stage  of  urban  development  in  the  Lao  PDR,  with  Vientiane  and  the  secondary 
towns having already developed as national and regional centers, the focus of development effort 
needs to shift to small towns to optimally utilize existing urban potentials to support broad-based 
development and reduce poverty in the urban and rural communities. There is need to improve 
infrastructure and services in these towns to attain a reasonable quality of life for the residents, 
especially  the  poor.  Investments  in  infrastructure  need  to  be  combined  with  efforts  to  improve 
livelihoods  through  pro-poor  microfinance  whereby  the  poor  and  micro  enterprises in the towns 
can  be  served  on  a  sustainable  basis.  Improvements  should  follow  inclusive  processes  to 
respond  to  the  community  demands  and  catalyze  the  resources  of  urban  residents.  All  these 
interventions  need  to  be  supported  by  developing  institutional  and  financial  frameworks 
conducive to sustainable urban service delivery through reinforcing and extending the reforms for 
decentralized urban governance to the small towns.

prominent feature of the Project is its support to the reforms for decentralized urban governance 
by  which  (i)  urban  administration  is  brought  closer  to  the  people;  (ii)  a  more  efficient,  demand-
responsive,  and  equitable  urban  service  delivery  is  ensured  at  the  local  level;  and  (iii)  local 
resources and especially the resources of the service recipients are mobilized. The Project will be 
instrumental  in  establishing  and  institutionalizing,  in  small  towns,  UDAAs  with  dedicated  urban 
functions and own sources of revenues and budgets. It will help in developing core capacities in 
UDAAs  and  pave  the  way  for  them  to  become  increasingly  competent  and  autonomous  urban 
local  governments.  Cost  recovery  for  O&M  of  urban  infrastructure  and  services  by  introducing 
and implementing user charges, fees, and other urban-based incomes is an essential element of 
decentralized  urban  governance  reforms.  The  relevant  assurances,  to  which  the  Government 
agreed,  are  given  in  para.  73.  The  urban  policy  and  institutional  reform  agenda  that  the 
Government agreed to is presented in Appendix 5.   
 
Sector Lending Approach. Another feature of the Project is its sector lending approach 
35. 
as  against  the  traditional  project  loan  approach.  The  sector  lending  approach  provides  the 
needed  flexibility  to  make  adjustments  as  implementation  proceeds,  and  hence  reinforces  the 
responsiveness  to  demand.  The  sector  lending  modality,  adopted  for  the  Project,  incorporates 
several  strategic  features  and  incentives  to  promote  demand  responsiveness  and,  more 
importantly, smooth implementation of the urban institutional and policy reform agenda. Entry into 
the  Project  is  conditioned  by  (i)  the  towns’  demonstrated  commitment  to  undertaking  urban 
institutional reforms by establishing UDAAs and (ii) contribution to a portion of the capital cost of 
investments.  The  towns,  to  be  admitted  into  the  Project,  are  required  to  prepare  time-bound 
operational  and  financial  action  plans  to  strengthen  UDAAs  and,  more  specifically,  to  increase 
their  revenues  and  develop  their  staffing  and  technical  capacities  in  a  progressive  manner 
(Appendix 4).

36. 
Poverty  Focus. The Project has a strong poverty orientation.  Specific  pro-poor features 
include  (i)  prioritizing  the  towns  with  higher  levels  of  poverty  for  inclusion  in  the  Project;  (ii) 
prioritizing  subprojects  with  higher  poverty  reduction  impact;  (iii)  promoting  inclusive  processes 
through  an  extensive  community  dialogue  and  partnering  program,  accompanying  physical 
investments;  (iv)  integrated  nature  of  interventions  addressing  the  multidimensional  nature  of 
poverty; (v) direct targeting of the poor within towns through the village upgrading and livelihood 
promotion  program;  and  (vii)  promoting  good  governance  by  establishing  in  small  towns  
decentralized  UDAAs  for  more  responsive  urban  management.  The  village  upgrading  and 
livelihood  promotion  component,  which  prioritizes  villages  with  higher  levels  of  poverty,  is 
designed to address the poor villages’ highest priority basic infrastructure and services needs, to 
be determined by the village communities themselves. It is also designed to improve the income-
generating  ability  of  the  poor  households.  The  specific  elements  of  the  program  include  (i) 
adequate  representation  of  the  poor  and  women  in  village  working  committees,  (ii)  allowing  the 
poorer villagers to contribute in kind to the cost of improvements, and (iii) promoting community-
based service delivery and village contracts for solid waste collection, by which the poor’s burden 
of service charges is relieved. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is presented in 
Appendix 6.       
 
37. 
Participatory  Approaches.  The  Project  puts  a  strong  emphasis  on  participatory 
approaches  by  incorporating  a  process  of  community  dialogue  into  all  stages  of  the  Project. 
Participatory processes at the town level are fostered under the village upgrading program where 
the  village  organizations  and  communities  are  assigned  a  major  role  in  planning,  implementing, 
operating,  and  maintaining  improvements.  To  ensure  that  the  intended  participatory  processes 
are  followed,  the  Project  provides  considerable  input  for  implementing  a  program  of  community 
dialogue  and  partnering,  involving  assistance  in  designing  and  implementing  consultative 
processes,  and  capacity  building  for  UDAA  staff,  village  organizations,  and  communities  for 
community-based improvements. It is planned that the existing structures in villages and districts 
of the Lao Women’s Union and, wherever possible, NGOs with relevant experience will also be 
utilized in these processes. 
  
38. 
Private Sector Participation. The Project promotes private sector participation in urban 
service delivery. In some small towns, the private sector has already been involved in solid waste 
collection and disposal services albeit in a rudimentary way. But, success is constrained primarily 
by  the  low  level  of  user  charges  and  fees,  which  are  inadequate  to  cover  the  full  cost  of 
operations;  and  the  limited  capacities  of  town  administrations  to  undertake  and  supervise 
privately  delivered  services.  The  strategy  of  the  Project,  therefore,  will  involve  enhancing  the 
capacity  of  UDAAs  (i)  to  formulate  and  manage  private  sector  operations,  and  (ii)  to  implement 
charges  and  fees  at  reasonable  levels  that  allow  local  entrepreneurs  to  achieve  a  satisfactory 
level of cost recovery and sustain their operations. The areas of private sector participation, with 
which  the  Project  may  become  involved,  are  solid  waste  management,  septic  desludging,  and 
management of public markets and bus stations. 
       
39. 
Environment. The initial screening of potential environmental impacts of the subprojects 
indicates that the subprojects will not affect environmentally sensitive areas, nor will they cause 
changes  in  the  physical,  biological,  and  social  environment.  Any  adverse  environmental  effects 
would  be  minor  and  easily  mitigated.  Indeed,  most  of  the  subprojects  will  bring  clear  positive 
environmental benefits. The proposed physical works are limited in scope and concern mainly the 
improvement  of  existing  facilities,  drainage  channels,  and  roads.  Where  sanitary  landfill  and 
septic disposal treatment sites are proposed, the necessary mitigating measures will be applied 
to minimize negative impacts. The summary initial environmental examination is in Appendix 7.

Resettlement.  The  resettlement  impacts  of  the  Project  appear  minimal.  Virtually  all 
physical  works  for  the  townwide  infrastructure  and  amenities  component  in  part  A  will  be  made 
within  existing  rights-of-way  to  avoid  land  acquisition.  Since  the  towns  are  small  and  are  not 
experiencing  uncontrolled  development,  there  is  no  encroachment  on  the  rights-of-way.  In  the 
case  of  village  upgrading,  one  criterion  for  subproject  selection  is  that  no  land  acquisition  or 
relocation  is  required.  The  only  component  that  will  involve  some  land  acquisition  is  the  landfill

resettlement  is  unavoidable,  carry  out  a  resettlement  plan  to  improve  or  restore  the  preproject 
living  standards  of  the  affected  families;  and  (iii)  provide  adequate  compensation,  at  least  at

Impact  on  the  Poor  and  Vulnerable.  All  the  project  interventions  will  either  directly  or 
indirectly  have  a  positive  impact  on  the  poor.  Where  the  interventions  do  not  directly  target  the 
poor,  socially  inclusive  processes  incorporated  into  the  Project  will  ensure  that  the  poor  will 
benefit  proportionately.  About  42,500  urban  poor  or  30%  of  the  population  will  benefit  indirectly 
from townwide infrastructure and services and environmental improvements. Road improvements 
will  enhance  the  mobility  of  the  urban  poor  and  provide  them  with  increased  access  to  income-
earning  opportunities.  Drainage  improvements  will  have  a  profound  impact  on  the  lives  of  the 
poor,  the  majority  of  whom  live  on  low-lying  land  prone  to  flooding.  Improved  solid  waste 
management and septic disposal and construction of more public toilets will reduce the frequency 
of illnesses in urban poor households, as well as the medical expenses associated with illnesses.  
 
64. 
The  village  upgrading  program,  where  the  poorest  villages  have  priority  for  basic 
infrastructure  and  services  improvements,  will  have  a  direct  impact  on  poverty  reduction.  About 
60 urban villages with high levels of poverty and an estimated 69,000 residents will benefit from 
improved  environment  and  basic  services.  The  greater  role  that  this  program  assigns  to  the 
villages will ensure that the improvements are responsive to the needs of the poor. The program 
for civic awareness, community dialogue, and partnering will help villagers, especially the poor, to 
play an active role in designing and implementing the village upgrading works. A significant gain 
from  the  program  will  be  the  improved  capacities  of  UDAAs  and  villages  for  community-based 
planning  and  service  delivery  and  a  sustainable  program  of  self-funded  activities  that  can  be 
replicated by the Government without project funds.

A  number  of  project  components  will  directly  and  indirectly  impact  on  sustainable 
livelihood  and  increased  income-earning  opportunities  for  the  towns’  populations,  especially  the 
poor. First, a direct impact on livelihoods will be achieved through the microfinance services to be 
delivered  by  a  sustainable  and  pro-poor  MFI  to  be  supported  under  the  Project.  An  estimated

including  social  intermediation  assistance  and  loans  –  to  support  them  in  acquiring  productive 
assets or working capital to develop viable livelihood enterprises. Complementary interventions, 
supporting both the demand and supply sides of microfinance while adhering to the principle of 
sustainability  will  have  a  profound  effect  on  the  lives  of  the  poor  who  currently  cannot  access 
credit  services.  Second,  improving  the  environments  of  public  markets  will  lead  to  increased 
incomes  for  market  vendors  who  form  one  of  the  major  livelihood  groups  in  small  towns.  Third, 
temporary  employment  will  be  created  during  construction  of  the  urban  infrastructure  and 
improvement  of  services.  The  use  of  labor-intensive  technologies  will  generate  employment.

The  Risks.  Potential  risks  that  may  undermine  or  impede  the  project  impacts  include 
71. 
those  related  to  (i)  the  reforms  for  decentralized  urban  governance,  (ii)  sustainability  of  urban 
infrastructure  and  services  in  small  towns  in  general  and  project  facilities  in  particular,  (iii) 
community  attitudes,  and  (iv)  technical  aspects.  The  major  risks  related  to  the  reforms  for 
decentralized  urban  governance  include  (i)  the  prolonged  process  of  enacting  the  local 
administration  bill  and  a  level  of  uncertainty  resulting  from  the  use  of  decrees as legal tools to 
implement  reforms,  and  (ii)  insufficient  concerted  action  to  support  the  process  for  establishing 
and developing UDAAs and mobilizing local resources. The risks to sustainability comprise, (i) the 
embryonic  capacities  of  UDAAs  in  small  towns,  including  the  capacity  for  O&M;  (ii)  overall 
insufficient funds for O&M, and the insufficient own source revenues of UDAAs; and (iii) lack of 
Government support in the form of staffing and transfer of other resources, and lack of technical 
and  advisory  support  to  UDAAs  from  relevant  central  and  provincial  departments.  Community-
related  risks  include  lack  of  community  cooperation  in  the  village  upgrading  component, 
reluctance  to  contribute  to  improvements,  and  lack  of  awareness  of  the  benefits  from 
investments.  The  technical  risks  entail  (i)  the  relatively  large  number  of  project  towns  spread 
throughout a large geographic area, with adverse implications for scarce project and Government 
resources to ensure quality and the participatory processes; and (ii) a centralized mode of project 
implementation, bypassing UDAAs and other local stakeholders. 
 
To  mitigate  these  risks,  the  Project  has  devised  a  strategy.  The  strategy  involves  (i)  an 
72. 
urban  policy  and  reform  agenda  and  associated  assurances  agreed  to  by  the  Government  as 
safeguards for mitigating risks to decentralized urban governance reforms; (ii) a capacity building 
component  devoted  to  help  UDAAs  in  establishing  and  developing  their  technical  and  financial 
capacities  and  cost  recovery  reforms;  (iii)  specific  measures  of  the  sector  lending  approach 
requiring the towns’ commitment to UDAA reforms before inclusion in the Project, and operational 
and  financial  action  plans  motivating  the  towns  to  reform;  and  (iv)  project  implementation 
arrangements  involving  national  and  provincial  committees  with  greater  potential  to  provide 
broad-based  and  concerted  support  for  UDAA  reforms.  All  these  measures  also  provide 
safeguards  to  mitigate  the  risks  to  sustainability  by  addressing  the  technical  and  financial 
requirements. Strengthening technical capacities of UDAAs in O&M forms an important element 
of  the  capacity  building  program.  The  impact  is  reinforced  by  the  decentralized  project 
implementation arrangements enabling UDAAs to gain the most from the process and increasing 
the  towns’  sense  of  ownership  of  the  project  facilities,  resulting  in  sustainability.  The  financial 
requirements  of  sustainability  are  addressed  through  the  local  resource  mobilization  reforms 
whose  major  thrust  is  to  provide  secure  and  stable  sources  of  income  for  operating  and 
maintaining urban infrastructure on a sustainable basis. The measures to mitigate risks related to 
community  attitudes  include  incorporating  into  the  Project  an  extensive  program  of  civic 
awareness  and  community  dialogue,  which  will  motivate  the  communities  to  participate  in  and 
contribute  to  improvements  and  thus  build  local  capacities  for  community-based  village 
upgrading.  The  risks  related  to  managing  and  implementing  a  project  in  a  large  number  of 
geographically  scattered  towns  is  mitigated  by  adopting  a  three-stage implementation approach 
that allows the optimum use of scarce project and Government resources.

LAO PDR URBAN SECTOR ANALYSIS AND SECTOR INVESTMENT PLAN  

 
The Lao PDR is essentially a rural country, with about 18% of the population living in urban1 
1. 
areas.  However,  since  the  mid-1980s,  the  expanded  marketing  and  industrial  opportunities 
following  economic  liberalization  stimulated  urban  growth.  As  a  result,  growing  numbers  of  rural 
people were drawn to the urban areas in search of better livelihoods. Although the economy is still 
largely rural, with agriculture accounting for some 50% of gross domestic product (GDP), the role 
of the urban sector is growing. During 1997-2001 the industry and services sector components of 
GDP  increased  at  average  annual  rates  of  8  and  6.2%,  respectively,  compared  with  5.3%  for 
agriculture,  implying  productivity  and  greater  opportunities  in  urban  areas.  Vientiane, the capital 
city,  is  the  largest  urban  center  with  a  population  of  about  200,000.  The  four  largest  provincial 
capital,  called  secondary  towns,  have  populations  of  20,000  to  60,000.  An  emerging  category of 
urban  settlements  is  the  small  towns2  with  populations  ranging  from  5,000  to  20,000  and  growth 
rates  of  up  to  4.3%  per  annum.  These  towns  perform  critical  administrative  functions,  and  are 
economic  links  between  the  rural  areas  and  national  and  international  markets.  They  are  the 
locations  of  immediate  markets,  transport  depots,  and  agricultural  processing  centers  in  the  rural 
hinterland.  With  aggregated  markets  of  relatively  higher  incomes,  these  towns  help  to 
commercialize and diversify agriculture in the rural region. The research and extension required for 
diversification and inputs to rural production are supplied in these towns. A large number of rural 
people  commute  daily  to  these  towns  to  exchange  their  rural  produce  with  urban  goods  and 
services.  Moreover,  towns  offer  the  rural  poor  labor  markets  during  the  off-farm seasons. The 
nonfarm employment provided in these towns is a sustainable alternative for the Lao PDR, where 
ecological sustainability is threatened by livelihoods dependent on natural resources.

7. 
The  Government  recognizes  the  significance  of  the  urban  areas  in  national development. 
The  Fifth  Five-Year  Socioeconomic  Plan  (2001-2005)  prioritizes  planning  and  developing  basic 
infrastructure  and  services  in  urban  areas,  including  small  towns.  The  Government’s  ambitious 
development goal is to reduce poverty by half by 2005 and eradicate it by 2010. The Government 
is keen on equitable growth and concerned with the important role of small towns in broad-based 
local  development.  The  poverty  reduction  partnership  agreement  signed  by  ADB  and  the 
Government in September 2001 includes small towns development as one of the key operational 
priorities  to  enhance  reciprocal  linkages  between  urban  and  rural  areas,  more  specifically  to  (i) 
integrate  rural  producers  with  urban  markets,  (ii)  enable  urban  entrepreneurs  to  trade  with  rural 
people,  and  (iii)  facilitate  access  of  the  rural  and  urban  population  to  international  markets.  It  is 
acknowledged that this vision requires interventions to meet basic human needs and stimulate the 
economy in small towns.  

Urban Policy, Governance, and Finance   

  
8. 
Increasing urbanization led to the Government’s recognition of the need for improved urban 
management.  As  a  result,  urban  governance  in  the  Lao  PDR  has  undergone  a  major  transition 
over the last 6 years. Until recently MCTPC and its departments were responsible for planning and 
managing  urban  as  well  as  rural  areas.  In  1995,  the  Government  launched  a  program  of 
decentralization  and  has  established  urban  development  administration  authorities  (UDAAs)  in 
Vientiane  and  four  secondary  towns,  with  the  aim  to  eventually  transform  them into autonomous 
urban local governments. The Government's commitment to decentralization has been reflected in 
a number of prime ministerial (PM) decrees, instructions, notifications, and policy statements. Most 
significant for the decentralization process are decrees 177/PM issued in 1997 and 14/PM in 1999, 
the operational instructions of 141/PM issued in 2000, the PMO Notice of 1461/PMO and Ministry 
of  Finance  Decision  of  2083,  both  issued  in  October  2002.  These  decrees  recognize  UDAAs  as 
legal entities solely responsible for urban areas, and define them as organizations within provincial 
and prefectural administrative apparatuses. UDAAs are delegated tasks to plan and manage urban 
development,  and  to  provide  infrastructure  and  services,  including  roads,  drainage,  solid  waste 
management  and  sanitation,  environmental  protection,  public  lighting,  and  maintenance  of  urban 
assets.  Moreover,  the  decrees  empower  UDAAs  to  raise  revenues,  within  the  levels  set  by  the 
central  Government,  from  a  range  of  sources  including  service  fees  and  charges,  income  from 
movable or immovable property, sharing of national taxes, getting loans, local and foreign grants, 
and  funds  from  the  central  Government.  UDAAs  are  entrusted  with  using  these  funds  to  perform 
their tasks. Finally, the decrees also give guidelines on the organizational and working procedures 
of UDAAs.

9. 
The Government regards decentralization not only as a means for effective management, 
but also a strategy for equitable growth and poverty reduction. It is now in the process of redefining 
the role and culture of the Government, and rationalizing central-local relations. In the framework of 
decentralization, villages are also underlined as the lowest levels of Government located within the 
proximity of urban communities and an important point of interface between the community and the 
Government.  Villages  are  envisaged  to  play  an  important  role  in  planning  and  monitoring 
development  activities  to  ensure  that  development  is  equitable  and  participatory.  Within  the 
framework  of  the  foregoing  decrees,  UDAAs  have  been  gradually  developing  themselves.  They 
have  made  varying  levels  of  progress,  with  the  Vientiane  UDAA  (VUDAA)  being  at  a  most 
advanced  stage  in  terms  of  organizational  and  technical  competence  as  well  as  local  revenue 
mobilization reforms. Since January 2001, VUDAA has levied and collected a wide range of direct 
and  indirect  user  charges  and  fees,  including  charges  for  solid  waste  collection,  desludging 
services;  and  fees  for  vehicle  parking,  building  permits,  advertising  signs,  lease  of  public  land, 
urban  obligation  fees  from  all  buildings  and  commercial  outlets,  and  surcharges  for  water, 
electricity, and fuel. These initiatives in the urban sector are also supportive of the national goals of 
the  Government  for  domestic  resource  mobilization  to  finance  recurrent  expenditures  for  social 
development and to sustain existing physical assets.    
 
However,  small  urban  centers  to  date  have  not  benefited  from  these  reforms.  Urban 
10. 
planning  and  provision  of  infrastructure  and  services  still  remain  within  the  responsibility  of  the 
provincial  and  district  departments  of  the  MCTPC.  These  departments,  with  limited  staff  and 
resources  and  widespread  responsibility  for  both  urban  and  rural  areas  in  their  respective 
provinces and districts, cannot cope with the diverse demands of the rapidly growing and densely 
populated towns that require dedicated management. The departments rely on the Government for 
their budget for providing and maintaining infrastructure. But there is little relationship between the 
budget  requirements  and  the  allocations  actually  received.  There  is  no  separate  budget  for 
maintaining  urban  infrastructure,  and  maintenance  is  severely  underfunded.  The  degree  of  cost 
recovery is minimal with user charges in most towns being confined to solid waste collection. In the 
absence  of  separate  accounts  maintained  for  the  services,  it  is  not  possible  to  establish  a 
relationship  between  revenues  and  cost  of  services.  The  situation  is  aggravated  by  the 
predominantly  rural  background  of  small  towns  communities  who  are  not  accustomed  to  the 
benefits  of  urban  services  for  which  they  are  reluctant  to  pay.  In  sum,  the  current  centralized 
institutional framework is not conducive to efficient service delivery and mobilizing local resources, 
and exacerbates the poor living conditions and state of infrastructure and services in small towns.  
 
11. 
There  is  need  to  extend  the  urban  sector  reforms  to  the  small  towns.  The  reforms  to  be 
pursued should build on the existing reforms, and incorporate lessons learned from earlier efforts. 
The  experience  with  UDAA  reforms  suggests  the  need  for  further  concerted  efforts  if  the 
momentum  of  the  reforms  would  be  maintained.  By  their  comprehensive  nature,  decentralization 
reforms  require  technical,  financial,  and  legal  interventions  by  a  number  of  agencies  at  various 
levels. The lack of an encompassing and permanent legal framework for urban local governments 
remains  an  issue,  and  has  to  be  resolved  in  the  medium  term  to  secure  urban  policy  and 
institutional reforms steadily evolving and operating over the last 6 years on the basis of decrees 
and  decisions.  The  review  of  past  efforts  also  shows  that  the  commitments  made  through  a 
number  of  PM  decrees  and  decisions  have  not  always  been  simultaneously  supported  by  other 
concerned agencies within the Government. While the financial and technical progress of VUDAA 
was relatively promising, the progress of UDAAs in some secondary towns has been constrained, 
in some cases, by inadequate support of provincial governments or, in other cases, inability of the 
concerned  line  ministries  to  actually  transfer  the  assets,  resources,  staff,  and  revenue  collection 
function to UDAAs. In sum, the scale of reforms toward an entirely distinct system of decentralized 
urban  governance  in  the  Lao  PDR  necessitates  more  dialogue  and  extensive  support  for  the 
reforms and long-term assistance for building the capacity of UDAAs.

Town Participation 

 
A. 
 
The Small Towns Development Sector Project targets urban centers, that have not yet 
1. 
been covered by other urban development projects and which have great potential to contribute 
to poverty reduction and growth not only within the towns themselves but also in their respective 
rural hinterland. To achieve the target, a systematic approach identified the small towns that will 
qualify  for  inclusion  in  the  Project.  Preparing  the  long  list  of  small  towns  followed  a  two-stage 
process. Throughout the country there are over 140 urban centers that are either provincial or 
district capitals. However, the majority of these towns are largely rural in character. Therefore, 
first, a population threshold of 5,000 was used for initial screening. This exercise produced a list 
of  42  towns.  Second,  more  comprehensive  criteria  were  applied  to  determine  which  of  the  42 
towns have stronger urban characteristics and have the potential for broad-based development. 
The  criteria  broadly  included  (i)  administrative  importance,  i.e.,  either  district  or  provincial 
capital;  (ii)  provincial  poverty  index;  (iii)  population  and  rank  in  size  in  the  province;  and  (iv) 
towns’ regional, subregional, and local role. As a result, 23 towns were identified. These towns 
form the long list of eligible towns from which the project towns were and will be selected on the 
basis of further criteria described in the following paragraphs.  
 
Urban towns to be included in the Project will need to demonstrate their commitment to 
2. 
the Project as well as to urban policy and institutional reforms. More specifically, the towns will 
be  required  (i)  to  agree  to  establishing  urban  development  administration  authorities (UDAAs) 
and  gradually  strengthening  their  capacity;  (ii)  to  commit  to  increasing  locally  generated 
revenues to gradually cover their operation and maintenance (O&M) costs by implementing cost 
recovery measures and applying user fees, charges, and other urban based taxes; and (iii) to 
agree to contribute in cash or in kind to a portion of the cost of the capital works to cover the 
vehicle and equipment cost of solid waste management and sanitation/investments.

approved by ADB. Upon acceptance into the Project each UDAA will prepare management and

3.  A  poverty  assessment,  conducted  in  the  pilot  small  towns,  under  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance,  indicates  that  the 
poverty incidence in the project towns is 30%, higher than the national urban poverty incidence. The assessment reveals that urban 
poverty is characterized by (i) lack of permanent occupation; (ii) insufficient and irregular income; (iii) limited access to education and 
health  care;  (iv)  deficient  basic  infrastructure and services such as roads and footpaths, sanitation and solid waste collection and 
disposal  systems,  and  flood  protection  works;  (v)  inadequate  nonfarm  employment  opportunities;  and  (vi)  lack  of  ownership  of 
productive assets. While there are no aggregate squatter areas in the towns in the traditional sense, poverty is dispersed throughout 
the  urban  villages,  with  some  villages  accommodating  much  larger  populations  of  the  poor  than  others.  Frequently,  a  few  poor 
families huddle behind the homes  of wealthier villagers. The poor live on undeveloped plots without street frontage or proper access 
roads. These plots are often poorly drained and prone to flooding. Conditions are unhygienic; water- and feces-borne diseases are 
highly  prevalent,  undermining  health  and  income-earning opportunities.  In  most  cases  physical  and  social  exclusion  act  together, 
resulting in a perpetual poverty cycle of poor access to basic infrastructure and services, poor health, and poor living conditions, low 
productivity,  and  low  incomes   of  the  poor.  The  poorest  of  the  poor  depend  on  markets  and  forests  as  their  main  income,  selling 
vegetables, and forest products and offering their labor as porters and cleaners. The medium poor can be subject to volatility, earning 
some money but vulnerable to changing external conditions. The simple poor are slightly better off, but yet cannot escape from the 
perpetual  poverty  cycle.  The  poverty  assessment  indicates  that  the  poor  in  small  towns  unanimously  prioritize  the  lack  of  basic 
infrastructure and services and the low incomes as the most severe problems that need to be addressed.     
 
5.  The Project adopts a highly pro-poor approach and will contribute significantly to poverty reduction by addressing the physical and 
social barriers adversely  affecting  the  urban  poor  in  the  Lao  PDR,  thereby  enabling  them  to  improve  their  overall  living  conditions. 
Specific  pro-poor  features  include  (i)  prioritizing  the  towns  with  higher  levels  of  poverty  for  inclusion  in  the  Project;  (ii)  prioritizing 
subprojects  with  higher  poverty  reduction  impact;  (iii)  promoting  inclusive  processes  through  an  extensive  community  dialogue  and 
partnering  program,  accompanying  physical  investments;  (iv)  integrated  interventions  addressing  the  multidimensional  nature  of 
poverty; (v) direct targeting of the poor within towns through village upgrading and the livelihood promotion program; (vi) promoting

responsive  urban  management;  and  (vii)  assigning  a  greater  role  to  villages,  hence  promoting  partnership  with  communities  and

These works are primarily aimed at decreasing the incidence of flooding in small towns, thereby 
reducing flood-related damages to life and property and decreasing the potential for the spread 
of waterborne diseases. The essentially small-scale nature of these storm drainage  works does
